metadata.title: Australian national Persistent Identifier (PID) strategy 2024
metadata.description: The Australian National Persistent Identifier Strategy is the culmination of a coordinated, comprehensive and collaborative process led by the Australian Research Data Commons (ARDC). It has been informed by extensive consultation through national workshops, working groups, webinars and via an open call for individual and group submissions. A National PID Strategy Taskforce comprised of senior stakeholders provided strategic advice and guidance. Released as a draft in July 2023, the Strategy has been refined through extensive and open co-design, consultation and engagement with the sector.

hits.title: Australian national Persistent Identifier (PID) strategy 2024

metadata.title: Unearthing research software
metadata.description:
This report was commissioned as part of the ARDC’s program to implement a national agenda for research software. Using machine learning techniques, it estimates that approximately 47% of 13,784 ARC grants between 2010 and 2019 gave rise to software infrastructure, tools or code of some kind. The percentage is also estimated to have gone up during the decade as the volume of grants increased.

High and rising levels of ARC-funded software production are estimated across disciplines and organisations, including in the humanities, arts and social sciences (HASS), where 25% of research grants created software despite the domain’s unique nature and methodologies. No significant relationship was found between funding amounts and the probability that the research will produce software.

In light of the abundance of research software created through ARC grants, the report calls for better documentation, discoverability and management of research software.

hits.title: Unearthing research software

metadata.title: HASS and Indigenous Research Data Commons co-design framework
metadata.description:
This is the co-design framework for designing the HASS and Indigenous Research Data Commons, an initative of the Australian Research Data Commons (ARDC).

In collaboration with Indigenous Australians, the research community, industry and government, the Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences and Indigenous Research Data Commons (HASS and Indigenous RDC) is harnessing research data to enhance Australian social and cultural wellbeing, and help Australia understand and preserve our culture, history and heritage.

Investment in the HASS and Indigenous RDC will be made based on opportunities identified in partnership with stakeholders in the humanities, arts, social sciences and Indigenous research communities, and the broader groups who contribute to and benefit from that research. We will seek to develop infrastructure that creates the greatest impact for research and researchers by co-designing that infrastructure with the people who will benefit from it.

Our consultation and co-design processes are based on established methods such as the TACSI Co-Design Framework. Development of our co-investment activities will follow the steps of:

  1. Problem Identification 
  2. Project Shaping
  3. Project Planning
  4. Endorsement.

The way that each step is implemented will vary depending on the scale, complexity and timeline of the activity. 

Learn more about the HASS and Indigenous Research Data Commons.

metadata.title: A simple API proposal for SKOS systems
metadata.description:
Technical implementers and users of SKOS vocabularies have occasionally mooted the idea of creating a simple, standard, RESTful-style API for SKOS vocab data access but no widely accepted one has yet emerged. In this presentation, we will propose that such an API be created that is based on the W3C's Content Negotiation by Profile [1] and the OGC Records API [2]. We will spell out the logic for these particular bases and demonstrate a form of such API in action. We believe that this API is simple to implement and use yet powerful and fills a function that other vocab-relevant like SPARQL do not.

KurrawongAI has long implemented an API for SKOS vocabularies that is close to the one proposed here, so we bring our operational experience of that implementation to this presentation. We are also working with the Open Geospatial Consortium to implement a flagship instance of this API, so we will discuss that work here too.

References

1. World Wide Web Consortium, Content Negotiation by Profile, https://w3c.github.io/dx-connegp/connegp/

2. Open Geospatial Consortium, OGC Records API, https://ogcapi.ogc.org/records/

hits.title: A simple API proposal for SKOS systems

metadata.title: Space Vocabularies: Research, Development, Alignment, and Formalization (RAFD) in Astronomy and Astronautics
metadata.description:
Applying conceptual, terminological, semantic, and ontological analysis to spaceflight and space sciences such as astronomy, the author describes their Space Knowledge Organization and Modeling project. With origins in 2011, the project conducts research and development of vocabularies and other knowledge organization systems (KOS) for astronautics and astronomy related topics. Specific research and activities include knowledge representation and reasoning, and other modeling and formalization processes. The ongoing development of domain and application specific vocabularies, other KOS, and proposed standards will be introduced. Alignment or harmonization of these systems, including external existing systems and relevant (inter)national standards, is another project track and goal. The concept of knowledge networks in relation to so-called knowledge commons, among other concepts such as FAIR and contemporary AI techniques, will likewise be summarized. In all, the project hopes to support and innovate for space data, sciences, and activities, and help address challenges therein. The project and author are actively open to formal support, including patrons, partners, work and study opportunities to sustainably pursue this promising line of research. Interested parties are encouraged to make contact.

References
1. Space Domain Knowledge Organization and Modeling, https://ontospace.wordpress.com
2. "Research & development in Astronautical Terminology A project summary and call for support", R.J. Rovetto, 73rd International Astronautical Congress, Adelaide, Australia, 2017.
3. "Orbital Debris Ontology, Terminology, and Knowledge Modeling", R.J. Rovetto, T.S. Kelso, and D.A. O'Neil. 1st International Orbital Debris Conference. December 2019. In NASA TRS. In Journal of Space Safety Engineering (Sept, 2020).
4. "An Ontological Architecture for Orbital Debris Data", R.J. Rovetto, (2015) Earth Science Informatics, 9(1), 67-82.
5. "Preliminary Results of the International Astronautical Federation Space Traffic Management Technical Committee #26 Working Group on Terminology" (2021),
Rovetto, Oltrogge, Strah, Skinner, Mark, Laurent, Lacroix, Kumar, Grattan, Alonso. In 11th IAASS Conference Managing Risk in Space.
6. "An Ontology-Based Virtual Orrery" Dr. D.A. O'Neil, R.J.Rovetto, NASA Technical Memorandum (2017-2021).

 

Version note

Addition of presentation slides

hits.title: Space Vocabularies: Research, Development, Alignment, and Formalization (RAFD) in Astronomy and Astronautics

metadata.title: The Ethics of Vocabulary Development and Use
metadata.description:
The ethics of vocabulary development and use, and similar knowledge organization systems (or semantic artifacts) is introduced. It is a seldom-discussed or explored topic, but it's relevance to contemporary computational research and data sciences is made clear, the motivating case being a more complex semantic artefact (namely ontologies). Broadly construed, this project includes the ethics of metadata, of semantics, of ontology, and similar artifacts. The ongoing project aims to complete and propose a set of principles for the ethics of these systems, as well as explore and identify the potential or actual ethical and moral implications of various aspects of these artifacts. Concerns and topics from the ethics of artificial intelligence and digital ethics are relevant and inform this research and development activity, such as privacy, bias, data- sharing, machine ethics, and so on. The project and author are actively open to formal support to sustainably pursue this promising line of research. Interested parties are encouraged to make contact.

References
1. Rovetto, R.J. The ethics of conceptual, ontological, semantic and knowledge modeling. AI & Soc (2023). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00146-022-01563-3
2. Rovetto, R.J., "Ethics of Semantics" in US2TS 2022
3. "The Ethics of Ontology", poster presented at OntoCommons 2nd Global Workshop (June 2023).
4. Rovetto, R.J., "Ethics in Ontology", (2013-present), Abstract via PhilPapers.
5. Ethics of Ontology GitHub page, http://purl.org/rrovetto/ethics-of-ontology

 

Version note

Addition of presentation slides

hits.title: The Ethics of Vocabulary Development and Use

metadata.title: Advancing HIVE-4-MAT's Capacity to Leverage Multiple Vocabularies
metadata.description:
HIVE (Helping Interdisciplinary Vocabulary Engineering) is a linked-data, automatic indexing application. HIVE dynamically integrates vocabularies and expedites semantic tagging of data and other digital resources. A HIVE innovation called HIVE-4-MAT was created to improve the interoperability and usability of material science vocabularies. HIVE-4-MAT contains over 30 vocabularies covering material science, its subdisciplines, and related fields such as chemistry. The application allows for many different user interactions which include exploring a vocabulary in the user interface, searching the vocabularies for any shared terms, and using a keyword extraction algorithm to search articles and find related keywords belonging to one or more of the vocabularies. Our presentation will present these functionalities, highlight recent algorithm speed and accuracy improvements, and share future development ideas.

 

Version note

Presentation updated to provide contextual information concerning funding

hits.title: Advancing HIVE-4-MAT's Capacity to Leverage Multiple Vocabularies

metadata.title: A sustainable model to maintain and promote vocabularies: the AGROVOC use case
metadata.description:
AGROVOC is a multilingual agricultural thesaurus developed by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). It serves as a controlled vocabulary and information retrieval tool for the agricultural domain. AGROVOC's usefulness lies in its contribution to standardization, interoperability, information retrieval, multilingual support, and data integration.

AGROVOC is curated by its editorial community through a collaborative and participatory approach. FAO facilitates the development and maintenance of AGROVOC, but actively involves experts, researchers, and practitioners from the agricultural domain and related fields. The AGROVOC editorial community consists of a number of institutions serving as focal points for specific languages or topics. The community's contributions and expertise are vital to ensure the vocabulary's relevance, accuracy, and coverage. Thanks to this, AGROVOC is available in up to 42 languages. Subject matter experts who are fluent in different languages contribute translations, ensuring the vocabulary's multilingual support and cross-cultural relevance. It also ensures that the vocabulary reflects the collective expertise and needs of those who use it, making AGROVOC a valuable and trusted resource for organizing and sharing agricultural knowledge.

There is growing interest in how AGROVOC can support and host technical vocabularies developed at institutional level. These vocabularies can be isolated, managed in spreadsheets, and many do not yet leverage the power of being FAIR. Bringing vocabularies within the AGROVOC umbrella does take considerable work and requires creating awareness of the benefits and advantages of using linked open data and encouraging individuals and organizations to use it consistently in their work. Demonstrating benefits and socializing the value of vocabularies is key: promoting the use of controlled vocabularies within a community or group of people, highlighting the advantages of improved information retrieval, better data integration, and safeguarding of valuable vocabulary work is needed.

References
1. Imma Subirats-Coll, Kristin Kolshus, Andrea Turbati, Armando Stellato, Esther Mietzsch, Daniel Martini, Marcia Zeng, AGROVOC: The linked data concept hub for food and agriculture, Computers and Electronics in Agriculture, Volume 196, 2022. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.compag.2020.105965
2. FAO. 2021. AGROVOC Semantic data interoperability on food and agriculture. Rome.

metadata.title: Defining Indigenous Data Custody and Governance: The case of frozen- negated pathways autonomous transformation and other unknown community  civilization.
metadata.description:
Vocabulary, language and data are a simultaneous or concurrent phenomenon with a historical reference and characterized by the value of indispensability. Functionally interwoven in time and place they find meaningful expression within society as it fulfills its mission on one hand and conveniently curving space in a global village where simultaneously it inputs and derives value to guarantee existence with integrity; safeguard against marginalization and risks in this digital phase. Highest form of expression of vocabulary, language and data constitute culture and history of society while the opposite is true signifying death or alternatively a literally disabled, marginalized people without institutional representation. Language, vocabulary and data have a generational dimension characterizing them as they transition from one phase to another more precisely from traditional society; colonial society; post-colonial society; lastly transformation-digital society influenced by scientific and technological development. Major questions arise regarding data storage, who collects and keeps it; data sources, classes and collection levels and methods; data classification or declassification; partnership in data institution development; data sharing; data storage technologies; development planning data; data collection and Smart Cities; data quality and management through phases; what do we loose or gain moving from this phase to the next? Alternatively, what is the LOSS- GAIN balance on each phase, the previous and forthcoming? Equally is the pathway deserved by all or an alternative is inevitable? Vocabulary, language and data play a complimentary role in these processes consistent with the level of cultural development and data management culture too. Depth and level of development of vocabulary determine data quality and its utility level, more precisely the way it uplifts the citizen and society on one hand or alternatively the way it condemns the same to ranks of dejection when the world is visibly advancing digitally vibrant in all circles of human life.

Acknowledgements
Recognition is owed ARDC Hosts; Midlands State University, Faculty of Arts and Humanities, Department of Development Studies new generation courses and programs. Equally, the ASC -AfCFTA Studies Centre with its innovative Pan African AfCFTA robust engagement and its "Transformative AfCFTA: Southern Sub Saharan Africa and GLOBE Issues" Newsletter greatly nourishes this generation changing submission.

References
AGENDA AFRICA 2063., 2015. The Africa We Want. Final Edition. April 2015. Popular Version. Addis Ababa: African Union Commission. pp 4.

ANDREW, HEYWOOD., 2011. Global Politics. Palgrave Foundations. New York: Palgrave MacMillan. pp 560.

ASC-AfCFTA NEWSLETTER., 2023. Transformative AfCFTA: Southern Sub Saharan Africa the GLOBE Issues. April Issue. Vol 1. Number 2. Edited by Chikowore G. Focusing on AfCFTA exploits Americas: Latin America and the Caribbean cross sector value. Harare: ASC -AfCFTA Studies Centre / CCLTZ Publishing House. p 38.

CHIKOWORE, GODFREY., 2017.Transformative essence of Japan Official Development Assistance Policy: Significance for millennium regional economic cooperation and integration in Southern and Sub Saharan Africa 1980-2015 and Post 2015 Agenda Phase. Harare: University of Zimbabwe Publications. pp119.

FORREST, E. BAIRD., WALTER, KAUFMANN., 2008. From Plato to Derrida. Philosophic Classics, Fifth Edition. Upper Saddle River. New Jersey: Pearson Prentice Hall. Upper Saddle River. New Jersey. pp1201.

FREDERICK, P. STUTZ., BARNEY, WARF., 2012. The World Economy: geography, business, development. International Edition. Boston: Pearson. pp 435.

HIGH LEVEL PANEL REPORT., 2015. A New Global Partnership: Eradicate Poverty and Transform Economies through Sustainable Development. UNSDGs. New York: UN Publications.

JORGE, J. E. GRACIA., GREGORY, M. REICHBERG., BERNARD, N. SCHUMACHER.,2008. The Classics of Western Philosophy: A Readers Guide. Malden: Blackwell Publishing. p 614.

KAULEMU, DAVID., 2010. Ending Violence in Zimbabwe. African Forum for Catholic Social Teachings. Harare: Konrad Adenauer Stiftung. Arupe College. p 146.

UN HFA (2005) Hyogo Framework for Action 2005-2015: Building the resilience of Nations and Communities to Disasters (Extract from the final report on World Conference on Disaster Reduction - A/CONF206/6). United Nations. p 29.

hits.title: Defining Indigenous Data Custody and Governance: The case of frozen- negated pathways autonomous transformation and other unknown community  civilization.

metadata.title: Learning From Language: Strategies for Building CAREful Vocabularies
metadata.description:
Language is, as Capak notes "one of the most intimate and most political of human activities. The power of naming in fact shapes and defines the institutions that structure so much of our lives" (Capak, 1987, xvi). The challenges of inclusion and diverse representation in our language and naming activities are not new. However, in an age when automation and AI play increasing roles in our data and information systems, it becomes even more critical to address the oft-invisible power of language to include or exclude. Building FAIR vocabularies for all therefore requires us to take up the ongoing challenge of maintaining vocabularies that are inclusive as well as actionable.

Paying attention to ethical considerations of vocabulary construction and use is a vital aspect of building FAIR vocabularies sufficiently representative of community diversity. Language is dynamic and diverse and transversing communities are more the norm than the exception. Consequently, our vocabularies need to be crafted through ongoing engagement with communities. Drawing on insights gained through training we have provided in cross-disciplinary contexts such as global health and government services, this presentation shares ideas about how to capture and locate language to accommodate its mutability. Our approach is strongly influenced by Bowker and Star (1999), who propose keeping political and organizational dimensions shaping a classification's creation accessible while responding to institutional arrangements necessitated by new contexts and emerging understandings. We will also demonstrate how the CARE principles emerging from indigenous data governance (Carroll et al, 2020) serve as valuable guides for more inclusive and participatory practice for all communities.

Designing with communities enables us to make space for the learning that emerges through practice and language use. By sharing some of the techniques we use in our work, we hope to help others build FAIR vocabularies connected to the representative richness of the communities represented in that language.

References -

1. Capek, Mary Ellen S., ED. 1987. A women's thesaurus. New York: Harper & Row.

2. Bowker, G.C. & Star, S. 1999. Sorting things out: classification and its consequences.Cambridge MA: MIT Press.

3. Carroll, S. R. et al. 2020. The CARE principles for Indigenous data governance. Data Science Journal. 19, 112.

hits.title: Learning From Language: Strategies for Building CAREful Vocabularies

metadata.title: Building domain specific vocabularies for packaging and archiving research and cultural data
metadata.description:
This presentation will cover a complete ecosystem showing tooling for creating vocabularies in the Schema.org Schema style, publishing them online so that URLs resolve to useful definitions for users (which is often NOT the case with linked data vocabularies, including quite widely used ones), generating user interfaces for editing metadata and data records that use the vocabularies via automatically generated Editor Profiles and show the resulting data in use in repository portals.

This work is built on the Research Object Crate (RO-Crate)(1) specification for linked-data object description which was designed to be as programmer and end-user friendly as possible.

Examples will be drawn from the Language Data Commons of Australia where the vocabulary ecosystem was largely developed and refined, as well as other projects that use this general approach including two ARDC co-investments in data integration, the OHRM and Heurist projects.

Acknowledgements
The Language Data Commons of Australia (LDaCA) project received investment ([https://doi.org/10.47486/HIR001](https://doi.org/10.47486/HIR001)) from the Australian
Research Data Commons (ARDC). The ARDC is funded by the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS).

Reference
1. Soiland-Reyes S, Sefton P, Crosas M, Castro LJ, Coppens F, Fernndez JM, et al. Packaging research artefacts with RO-Crate. Data Sci. 2022 Jan 1;5(2):97138.

 

Version note

Corrects a spelling error in the presentation

hits.title: Building domain specific vocabularies for packaging and archiving research and cultural data

metadata.title: Geoscience Australia Vocabularies as a FAIR'ly useful communication tool
metadata.description:
Vocabularies or data dictionaries reflect agreed terms and their definitions as used by an organisation or domain specific community. Further, if the publisher of the vocabulary repository is trusted both in content and delivery, then it will support interoperability by allowing terms to be re-used or matched in other repositories.

Vocabularies published by GA are a relatively new communications tool and comprise three sub-types:

1. Controlled code lists

2. Glossaries or data dictionaries

3. Reference information

Currently the most important thing about vocabs at GA is in the creation of the vocab in the first place. We have many control lists in the building and needed a process for creating vocabs for non-technical users and a means to encourage consistency of understanding. Increasingly we have domain communities that are recognising the value of vocabularies and are interested in developing them.

Our vocabularies are being used as reference for terms in GA's catalogue and products such as web services. However, the machine-to-machine incorporation of vocabs into GA applications and databases is an aspiration - currently they are persistent but static reference objects. This presentation will cover the vocabulary publishing process at GA and a user's experience in managing a glossary to be used across government organisations.

hits.title: Geoscience Australia Vocabularies as a FAIR'ly useful communication tool

metadata.title: The role of vocabularies in cultural heritage and the impact of new strategic drivers
metadata.description:
The NFSA collection covers video games, film, television, sound, radio, oral history, documents, and artefacts that reflect Australian audio-visual industries, history, and culture. NFSA is revising its collection data model from traditional records-based cataloguing to a knowledge graph and drawing upon the FRBR model generated by the library world to structure information conceptually (works/expressions) through to the versions of those expressions (files/items). Works/expressions have a mix of vocabulary information ranging from forms and genre (conceptual in nature) to artefact and media types (material in nature). Therefore, vocabulary terms may be consistent across all classes e.g., genre, or they may be applied at specific points in the class structure e.g., media type. The interlacing of the FRBR model and conceptual and actual vocabulary terms is significant. Conceptual information aids in understanding the breadth and quality of the collection and material information aids in understanding the nature of collection management (including digitisation and preservation). The impact of the new collection data model on NFSA operations, is that it will streamline data access, enhance governance, efficiency, and insights, ultimately empowering NFSA to better share their rich audio-visual heritage. Vocabularies play a critical role as "translation tools" that structure, categorise, and decipher vast data sets, ensuring accessibility, interoperability, and deeper understanding of cultural heritage data. Examples from the NFSA collection highlight the power of conceptual and material vocabularies for research and collection management.

Version note

Abstract edited to clarify terminology, replacing "stories" with "works/expressions".  Originally, "stories" referred to the upper layer of content group 1, but this terminology may prove confusing since stories are not exclusive to one layer but are present across various layers of the model.

creators.name: Drysdale, Jen
creators.affiliation: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

hits.title: The role of vocabularies in cultural heritage and the impact of new strategic drivers

metadata.title: Building the AusTraits Plant Dictionary into a formal vocabulary
metadata.description:
The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) is the most complete formal vocabulary for ecological plant trait concepts, offering a resource for all researchers seeking semantically clear, well-defined plant trait definitions to apply to other datasets or reuse in other vocabularies. Without formal trait concepts, distinct datasets cannot be linked, limiting their reuse. The trait concepts were initially informal definitions required to compile the AusTraits database, a large, open-source, harmonised database of Australian plant trait data. Having a formal vocabulary of trait concepts is essential for the interpretation of the trait values within AusTraits, necessitating the transformation of the initial resource into a formal vocabulary, output in both human-friendly and machine-readable formats. This required three core steps, 1) Review of all trait concepts, trait definitions, and allowable categorical trait values; 2) Addition of metadata to each trait concept; 3) Building the trait dictionary into an rdf representation with resolvable URI's for each trait concept and categorical trait value. Metadata for each trait include a trait label, trait definition, units, allowable ranges (for numeric traits), allowable values (for categorical traits), structure measured, characteristic measured, keywords, references, reviewers, and links to identical/similar/related concepts in other trait dictionaries and databases. R scripts were developed to build the rdf representation from spreadsheets, offering a transparent, reproducible workflow that is intuitive to most ecology researchers and allowing new traits to easily be added to the vocabulary. 

Version note

Corrects a formatting error in the original presentation file introduced during file conversion.

hits.title: Building the AusTraits Plant Dictionary into a formal vocabulary

metadata.title: Accelerating Machine-to-Machine Interoperability of Geoscience Data through using FAIR Implementation Profiles (FIPs) and FAIR Enabling Resources (FERs) to Declare Semantic Resources Implemented in any Dataset.
metadata.description:
The Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable (FAIR) principles of Wilkinson et al. (2016) were designed to improve reuse of scholarly data by emphasising the ability of machines to find, access, aggregate and reuse data. Although many data producers strive to make their datasets FAIR, most datasets only meet the findable and accessible principles: few are fully machine-interoperable as there is insufficient specificity and granularity regarding implementation of standards, formats, and in particular, vocabularies.

In 2020, to accelerate FAIR convergence, FAIR Implementation Profiles (FIPs) were introduced to declare the implementation choices made by a community of practice for each FAIR principle pertaining to a dataset (Shultes et al. 2020). The effectiveness of any FIP relies on machine actionable descriptions of all individual resources being used to describe a dataset, which in turn requires the publication of each individual FAIR-Enabling Resource (FER) for each principle.

The second Interoperable Principle (I2) requires "(meta)data use vocabularies that follow FAIR principles"(Wilkinson et al. 2016). However, few vocabularies meet this requirement: many are published as static PDFs. Even where each term in a vocabulary is published with a PID in a version-controlled vocabulary service, the vocabulary itself (and even the service) may not be identified with a resolvable PID and it can be hard to access the superseded versions. To provide a machine actionable reference, each vocabulary needs to be uniquely identified with a PID that is version controlled and time-stamped, so that the precise vocabularies used to describe any published dataset can be referenced and accessed over time. For large and complex vocabularies, this may necessitate the publication of custom time-stamped implementation profiles of the source vocabulary.

Using examples from geophysics and geochemistry, this presentation will show how FIPs, combined with FERs, can accelerate semantic interoperability of datasets acquired by different communities/repositories and at scale.

Acknowledgements
Work presented here was developed as part of the:
1. WorldFAIR: Global Cooperation on FAIR Data Policy and Practice Project which has received co-funding from the European Commission's WIDERA coordination and
support programme under the Grant Agreement no. 101058393. (https://worldfair-project.eu/ ); and

2. Building a National High-resolution Geophysics Reference Collection for 2030 Computation Project (https://ardc.edu.au/project/2030-geophysics-collections/) which was co-funded by AuScope, National Computational Infrastructure (NCI), Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) and the Australian Research Data Commons
(ARDC) https://doi.org/10.47486/XN002 as part of the Australian National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) program.

References
1. Schultes E, Magagna B, Hettne KM, Pergl R, Suchnek M, & Kuhn T (2020). Reusable FAIR Implementation Profiles as Accelerators of FAIR Convergence. In: Grossmann
G & Ram S (eds) Advances in Conceptual Modeling. ER 2020. Lecture Notes in Computer Science, vol 12584. Springer, Cham. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030- 65847-2_13

2. Wilkinson MD, Dumontier M, Packer AL, Gray AJG, Mons A, Gonzalez-Beltran A, Waagmeester A, Baak A, Brookes AJ, Evelo CT, Mons B, Persson B, Goble C, Schultes E, van Mulligen E, Aalbersberg IjJ, Appleton G, Boiten J-W, Dillo I, Grethe JS, Heringa J, Strawn G, Velterop J, Bouwman J, van der Lei J, Kok J, Zhao J,
Wolstencroft K, da Santos LB, Roos M, Thompson M, Martone ME, Crosas M, Swertz MA, Axton M, Blomberg N, Dumon O, Groth P, 't Hoen PAC, Wittenburg P, Bourne PE, Rocca-Serra P, van Schaik R, Finkers R, Hooft R, Kok R, Edmunds S, Lusher SJ, Sansone S-A, Slater T, Sengstag T, Clark T & Kuhn T (2016). The FAIR Guiding
Principles for scientific data management and stewardship. Scientific Data, 3: 160018. DOI: https:// doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2016.18

hits.title: Accelerating Machine-to-Machine Interoperability of Geoscience Data through using FAIR Implementation Profiles (FIPs) and FAIR Enabling Resources (FERs) to Declare Semantic Resources Implemented in any Dataset.

metadata.title: International Classification of Diseases 11th Revision Comprehensive Clinical Linearization (ICD-11_CCL)
metadata.description:
In 2007, the World Health Organization (WHO) began a revision and restructuring of the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems, 10th revision (ICD-10) to transform this classification system into a flexible clinical and research friendly structure aligned with advances in information technology. The 11th revision was endorsed by the World Health Assembly at its 72nd meeting in 2019 for implementation beginning in January 2022.(1)

ICD-11 is part of the WHO Family of International Classifications (WHO-FIC) Foundation. The Foundation is a multidimensional collection of all WHO-Family of Classifications (WHO-FIC) entities.(2) ICD-11 linearizations are produced from the ICD-11 Foundation for a particular purpose, for example, ICD-11 for Mortality and Morbidity (ICD-11 MMS).

Many countries, such as the United States, Australia, and Canada, created ICD-10 modifications and have several use cases for them. This makes transitioning the legacy systems to ICD-11 MMS difficult due to the need to determine if ICD-11 MMS is "fit for purpose" and if not, what should the process be going forward. Initial findings suggest there are clinical entities in these country specific modifications that are not found in ICD-11 MMS. So, the question becomes, should a country specific linearization be developed?

Recognizing ICD-11's potential, the authors, with support of the RADIUS Collaborative, have created the ICD-11 Comprehensive Clinical Linearization, Evolution and Response (C-CLEAR). ICD-11 C-CLEAR (ICD-11_CCL) is a linearization that aligns with ICD-11 MMS but also extends it using the Foundation's content. The ICD-11_CCL syntax transforms free clinical text in which the same clinical concept can be expressed in many ways into a single unique ICD-11_CCL coded representation of a clinical concept, that is a post-coordinated code cluster, which then can be tailored into healthcare analytic categories.

ICD-11_CCL also supports country specific content that takes into account legacy codes not currently found in ICD-11 MMS.

Acknowledgements

The RADIUS Collaborative is a volunteer group of professionals representing medicine, informatics, healthcare data, computer technology, analytics, performance evaluation, economics, and payment.

References

1. "The 72nd World Health Assembly resolution for ICD-11 adoption WHO." May 27, 2019. https://www.who.int/publications/m/item/eleventh-revision-of-the-international-classification-of-diseases-adoption-wha72.BODC. 'BODC-Approved Data Storage Units (P06)'. https://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P06/current/.

2. WHO-FIC Content Model Reference Guide, World Health Organization (WHO) 2021 https://icd.who.int/browse11. Licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivatives 3.0 IGO licence (CC BY-ND 3.0 IGO).

hits.title: International Classification of Diseases 11th Revision Comprehensive Clinical Linearization (ICD-11_CCL)
